___name.description: A collection's friendly name is defined by this field. You would want to set this field to a value that would allow you to easily identify this collection among a bunch of other collections, as such outlining its usage or content.

items.description: A request represents an HTTP request.
items.title: Request

___rawModeData.description: Contains the raw data (parameters) that Postman sends to the server

___responses.description: A Postman request can have multiple responses associated with it. These responses are stored in this field.

items.description: A response represents an HTTP response.
items.title: Response

___language.description: The language associated with the response.

___name.description: A response can have a friendly name, which goes here.

___text.description: The raw text of the response.

___time.description: The time taken by this particular HTTP transaction to complete is stored in this field.

___request.description: A response is associated with a request. This fields contains the UUID of the request corresponding to this response.

___detail.description: Detailed explanation of the response code.

___name.description: This is the name of the Cookie.

___httpOnly.description: Indicates if this cookie is HTTP Only.

___session.description: True if the cookie is a session cookie.

___hostOnly.description: Indicates if this cookie is Host Only.

___expirationDate.description: The timestamp of the time when the cookie expires.

___secure.description: Indicates if the 'secure' flag is set on the Cookie.

___storeId.description: The ID of the cookie store containing this cookie.

___domain.description: The domain for which this cookie is valid.

___path.description: The path associated with the Cookie.

___name.description: Some headers can have names associated with them, which are stored in this field.

___description.description: An optional description about the header.

___key.description: The left hand side (LHS) or 'key' of the header.

___value.description: Value of the header, or the right hand side (RHS).

___id.description: In order to unambiguously identify a response, Postman assigns a UUID to it, and stores it in this field.

___rawDataType.description: The data type of the raw response.

___dataMode.description: A request can have a specific data mode, and Postman supports three.

___method.description: The HTTP method associated with this request.

___tests.description: Postman allows you to define a script that is run after executing the request, which may act on the response. Such a script is stored in this field.

___folder.description: Postman requests may or may not be a part of a folder. If this request belongs to a folder, that folder's unique ID (which is a [UUID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globally_unique_identifier)) is stored in this field.

___descriptionFormat.description: A request can have an associated description text. Since description is meant to be long, it can be in either ``html`` or ``markdown`` formats. This field specifies that format.

___pathVariables.description: A Postman request allows you to use Path Variabled in a request, e.g: ``{{url}}``. This field stores these variables.

___name.description: Sometimes, you just need to call your request 'Bob'. Postman will let you do that, and store the name you give in this field.

___description.description: The description of this request. Can be as long as you want. Postman also supports two formats for your description, ``markdown`` and ``html``.

___url.description: Contains the complete URL for this request, along with the path variables, if any.

___preRequestScript.description: In some use cases, it's necessary to run a bit of code or perform some tasks before sending a request. Postman implements this feature by the use of this field. Any code written to this field is run before running a request.

___headers.description: No HTTP request is complete without its headers, and the same is true for a Postman request. This field contains all the HTTP Headers in a raw string format.

___id.description: Postman can store a number of requests in each collection. In order to preserve the order of each request, we need to be able to identify requests uniquely. This field is a UUID assigned to each request.

___data.description: Data is an array of key-values that the request goes with. POST data, PUT data, etc goes here.

___order.description:
The order array ensures that your requests and folders don't randomly get shuffled up. It holds a sequence of [UUIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier) corresponding to folders and requests.
 *Note that if a folder ID or a request ID (if the request is not already part of a folder) is not included in the order array, the request or the folder will not show up in the collection.*

___description.description: Provide a long description of this collection using this field. This field supports markdown syntax to better format the description.

___folders.description: Folders are the way to go if you want to group your requests and to keep things organised. Folders can also be useful in sequentially requesting a part of the entire collection by using [Postman Collection Runner](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/jetpacks_running_collections) or [Newman](https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman) on a particular folder.

items.description: One of the primary goals of Postman is to organize the development of APIs. To this end, it is necessary to be able to group requests together. This can be achived using 'Folders'. A folder just is an ordered set of requests.
items.title: Folder

___name.description: A folder's friendly name is defined by this field. You would want to set this field to a value that would allow you to easily identify this folder.

___order.description: Postman preserves the order of your requests within each folder. This field holds a sequence of [UUIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globally_unique_identifier), where each ID corresponds to a particular Postman request.

___collection.description: Postman folders are always a part of a collection. That collection's unique ID (which is a [UUID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globally_unique_identifier)) is stored in this field.

___description.description: Essays about the folder go into this field!

___id.description: In order to be able to uniquely identify different folders within a collection, Postman assigns each folder a unique ID (a [UUID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globally_unique_identifier)). This field contains that value.

Every collection is identified by the unique value of this field. The value of this field is usually easiest to generate using a [UID](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4122#section-4.4%29) generator function. If you already have a collection, it is recommended that you maintain the same id since changing the id usually implies that this is a different collection than it was originally.
